snippet: Lam Wing-kee, whose Hong Kong bookstore sold gossipy books about China’s leadership, says he was detained at the border by captors who wanted customers’ details.
abstract: Hong Kong bookseller Lam Wing-kee, whose store sold sensational gossipy books about Chinese Communist leadership, says he was abducted at Chinese border and spent five months in solitary confinement; at news conference, Lam says he was permitted to leave by promising to return with customer information; narrative contradicts China's claims that Lam and four other booksellers voluntarily entered country, and could hurt China's image.

byline.original: By ALAN WONG, MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ANDREW JACOBS
byline.contributor: Alan Wong and Michael Forsythe reported from Hong Kong, and Andrew Jacobs from New York.

lead_paragraph: Lam Wing-kee, whose Hong Kong bookstore sold gossipy books about China’s leadership, says he was detained at the border by captors who wanted customers’ details.

headline.main: Defying China, Hong Kong Bookseller Describes Detention
